rich_narrative.summary: The Sierra Club Foundation, <cite id="1">founded in 1960</cite>, serves as a critical financial engine for environmental protection and climate solutions across the United States. Managing <cite id="2">$89,068,739 in total revenue</cite> as of its most recent filings, the Foundation primarily functions as a fiscal sponsor for charitable programs that promote a transition to a resource-efficient clean energy economy. Its strategic philanthropy supports large-scale initiatives such as <cite id="4">Clean Power Plan Advocacy and Public Interest Litigation</cite>, which aim to secure protections for public lands and waters. The organization maintains a <cite id="5">platinum seal of transparency from Candid</cite>, reflecting a high level of voluntary data sharing regarding its operations and goals. Financially, the Foundation demonstrates high efficiency, directing <cite id="6">86.0% of its expenses toward program services</cite> and maintaining <cite id="7">17.7 months of working capital</cite> to ensure long-term stability for its advocacy campaigns. While it does not provide direct humanitarian aid in the traditional sense, its work in <cite id="8">climate change mitigation</cite> addresses systemic environmental risks that disproportionately affect vulnerable global populations.
